feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Montgomery

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 20 at 2:18PM EST until December 21 at 10:00PM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Lake effect snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 7 inches across much of Geauga County, southern Lake County, and inland Ashtabula County. Accumulations of 2 to 5 inches are expected in northern Ashtabula County, north of I-90 in Lake County, and southern and eastern Cuyahoga County. Western Cuyahoga County will see lighter accumulations.
* WHERE...Ashtabula Inland, Ashtabula Lakeshore, Cuyahoga, Geauga, and Lake Counties.
* WHEN...Until 10 PM EST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Friday evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A burst of snow will accompany a front this evening followed by lake effect snow showers. A narrow band of heavier snow connected to Lake Huron is expected to drift across parts of eastern Lake, Geauga, and Ashtabula Counties for much of Saturday with rates up to 1 inch per hour. If this band is persistent in one area, locally higher amounts are possible.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cuyahoga; Lake; Geauga; Ashtabula Inland; Ashtabula Lakeshore

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 PM EST SATURDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 20 at 2:18PM EST until December 21 at 10:00PM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations of 3 to 6 inches across the higher terrain south of I-90. Snow amounts will be lighter close to the immediate lakeshore, and will gradually drop off towards the Crawford County border.
* WHERE...Northern Erie and Southern Erie Counties.
* WHEN...Until 10 PM EST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions with slower travel likely. The hazardous conditions could impact the Friday evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Steady light to moderate lake enhanced snow will re-develop this evening, with potential for impacts to roads increasing after sunset. Steady and more widespread light to moderate snow will transition to narrower bands of lake effect snow for Saturday, with accumulations becoming confined to higher terrain locations on Saturday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Erie; Southern Erie

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 PM EST SATURDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 20 at 2:18PM EST until December 21 at 10:00PM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Lake effect snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 5 inches where bands are most persistent, mainly across northern and eastern Portage County and much of Trumbull County. Locally higher amounts in excess of 6 inches are possible in northern Trumbull County. Amounts decrease across southern Portage County.
* WHERE...Portage and Trumbull Counties.
* WHEN...From 7 PM this evening to 10 PM EST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions with slower travel likely.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Untreated surfaces have the potential to turn slick this evening as light snow showers continue and temperatures drop below freezing. Heavier lake effect snow bands are expected to begin developing after midnight and into Saturday morning. The main focus will be a narrow band of heavier snow with a connection to Lake Huron, which may become persistent across Trumbull County for much of Saturday while drifting into Portage County at times.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Portage; Trumbull

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 7 PM THIS EVENING TO 10 PM EST SATURDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 20 at 1:14PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary: Snow, moderate at times, will move across central North Dakota this afternoon. Visibility down to a mile can be expected with this band of snow. In addition, gusty winds may bring further visibility reductions in areas of snow and blowing snow. Those traveling should slow down when encountering moderate snowfall.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Burke; Renville; Mountrail; Ward; Dunn; Mercer; Oliver; McLean; Morton; Burleigh; Grant; Sioux; Emmons

cap:parameter.value: A BAND OF MODERATE SNOW TO IMPACT CENTRAL NORTH DAKOTA THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Flood Warning issued December 20 at 10:59AM PST until December 26 at 3:51AM PST by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Washington...
Skokomish River At Potlatch affecting Mason County.
.The Skokomish River will slowly recede and remain near or within Minor flood stage through this evening.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Skokomish River at Potlatch.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow morning.
* IMPACTS...At 16.5 feet, the Skokomish River will cause widespread flooding of pasture lands, with water flowing quickly over West Bourgault Road and Skokomish Valley Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM PST Friday the stage was 16.9 feet. - Flood stage is 16.5 feet. - Forecast...The river will fall below flood stage late this evening to 16.3 feet. It will then rise above flood stage Sunday afternoon to 16.7 feet early Monday morning and further rises are possible. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mason, WA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW MORNING

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued December 21 at 3:51AM ChST until December 22 at 6:00AM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...East facing reefs of the Marianas.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL INFORMATION...The east swell is expected to diminish over the next day or so, however a strong north swell will likely take its place around Sunday. This new swell may cause the risk to on north and west facing reefs to become high.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Guam; Rota; Tinian; Saipan

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 20 at 12:15PM EST by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
Rain will begin this afternoon and change to snow later this afternoon as temperatures fall into the mid 30s and lower. Scattered snow showers will continue at least through the evening tonight. A dusting to one-half inch of snow will be possible across the Cumberland Plateau and lower elevations of northeast Tennessee. Accumulations will be mainly grassy surfaces and higher exposed objects. Ridgetops and higher peaks along the plateau may have localized amounts of up to 1 inch of snow.
Slow down and use caution if traveling across the higher elevations this afternoon and overnight tonight. Be prepared for the possibilty of snow covered roadways and locally icy conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Scott; Campbell; Claiborne; Hancock; Hawkins; Sullivan; Morgan; Union; Grainger; Hamblen; Northwest Cocke; Northwest Greene; Washington; Northwest Carter; Jefferson; North Sevier; Sequatchie; Bledsoe; Scott

cap:parameter.value: Light Snow Accumulations this afternoon through this evening

entry.title: Flood Warning issued December 20 at 10:30AM CST by NWS Little Rock AR
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Arkansas...
Cache River Near Patterson affecting Woodruff and Jackson Counties.
For the Cache River...including Patterson...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Cache River near Patterson.
* WHEN...From Saturday afternoon until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Pastureland and cropland not protected by levees in Jackson and Woodruff counties affected. Water is over portions of State Highway 37 and deep along the shoulders of State Highway 18 near Grubbs. Water over portions of Woodruff County Road 775 north of State Highway 260.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:15 AM CST Friday the stage was 8.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early tomorrow afternoon and continue rising to 10.0 feet early Tuesday afternoon. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 9.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jackson, AR; Woodruff, AR

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued December 20 at 9:30AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
AQAPSR
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued a PM-2.5 High Pollution Advisory for the Phoenix Metro Area through Sunday.
This means that ongoing stagnant weather conditions combined with existing airborne fine particulate levels may result in local fine particulate concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates.
Fine particulate matter - also known as PM-2.5 - is an air contaminant that can aggravate heart and lung disease conditions, especially in older adults, children, and those with asthma. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.
Consolidate your travel, reduce or eliminate fireplace use, refrain from outdoor burning, and avoid using gas-powered lawn equipment.
For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/phoenix or call 602-771-2300.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Maricopa, AZ

cap:parameter.value: PM-2.5 HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR MARICOPA COUNTY INCLUDING THE PHOENIX METRO AREA THROUGH SUNDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 20 at 11:24AM EST until December 21 at 6:00AM EST by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A mixture of snow and rain will develop today and then become all snow by late in the day. The snow will transition to snow showers this evening and then taper to flurries during the night. Total snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches are expected for most locations, with the most significant accumulations expected above elevations of 1500 feet.
* WHERE...The Winter Weather Advisory is for a portion of southeast Kentucky.
* WHEN...the Winter Weather Advisory is in effect until 6 AM EST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Friday evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...With valley temperatures above freezing today, most of the initial snow is likely to melt there. However, as temperatures fall to around freezing in valleys early this evening, those locations can also expect light accumulations.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bell; Harlan; Knott; Perry; Leslie; Letcher; Pike

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM EST SATURDAY

.Heavy rain from earlier this week caused the river to rise.

Green River at Rochester affecting Muhlenberg, Ohio and Butler Counties.
Green River at Woodbury affecting Butler and Warren Counties.
.Heavy rain from earlier this week caused the river to rise.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Green River at Rochester.
* WHEN...Until late tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 34.0 feet, Rochester Ferry stops operation. At 37.0 feet, Reeds and Rochester Ferries remain closed. KY 369 floods one mile north of Rochester.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 AM CST Friday the stage was 38.1 feet. - Bankfull stage is 34.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:45 AM CST Friday was 38.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 32.4 feet Wednesday morning. - Flood stage is 37.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 39.0 feet on 03/22/2020. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Butler, KY; Muhlenberg, KY; Ohio, KY

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued December 20 at 7:53AM PST until December 27 at 2:00AM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves with dangerous rip currents. Surf will be highest across west and northwest facing beaches. For the Central Coast Beaches, breaking waves of 12 to 18 feet with local sets to 20 feet are expected, except 18 to 25 feet Monday into Tuesday. For the Santa Barbara South Coast Beaches, breaking waves of 6 to 10 feet are expected, except 8 to 12 feet Monday afternoon into Tuesday. For the Ventura County beaches, breaking waves of 8 to 12 feet with local sets to 15 feet are expected, except 10 to 17 feet Monday night into Tuesday.
* WHERE...San Luis Obispo County Beaches, Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches, Santa Barbara County Southwestern Coast, Santa Barbara County Southeastern Coast and Ventura County Beaches.
* WHEN...From 2 AM Saturday to 2 AM PST Friday.
* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats near shore.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A high surf warning will likely be needed Monday night through Tuesday for the Central Coast and Ventura County beaches, and may be needed for the Santa Barbara South Coast. Additionally, minor coastal flooding and beach erosion are possible, especially during the morning high tides Monday into Tuesday. High tides will be between 4.4 and 4.7 feet and occur between 4 and 5 AM PST.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued December 20 at 7:51AM MST by NWS Tucson AZ
entry.summary:
AQATWC
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued a PM-10 High Pollution Advisory for Nogales on Friday.
This means that ongoing stagnant weather conditions may result in local PM-10 concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates.
Coarse particulate matter - also known as PM-10 - is an air contaminant that can aggravate heart and lung disease conditions, especially in older adults, children, and those with asthma. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.
Consolidate your travel, stabilize loose soils, slow down or avoid travel on dirt roads, reduce or eliminate fireplace use, and avoid using gas-powered lawn equipment.
For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/nogales or call 602-771-2300.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Santa Cruz, AZ

cap:parameter.value: PM-10 HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR SANTA CRUZ COUNTY INCLUDING NOGALES THROUGH SATURDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 20 at 5:48AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Multiple storms will move into the Gulf over the weekend, sending a series of fronts into the coast. Periods of light rain and freezing rain are expected Saturday through Monday, with the most likely time for precipitation being Saturday night into Sunday morning. Currently the most likely areas to receive rain or freezing rain are: near sea level locations in Anchorage, particularly east Anchorage, the Western Kenai Peninsula east of Soldotna, and the Mat Valley near Palmer. Of the above areas, the Mat Valley is the least likely to get precipitation, but any falling will likely be in the form of rain.
Given the somewhat warm surface temperatures of 29 to 36 degrees, for now, it's unlikely that rain would freeze onto surfaces like power lines and trees, but rain falling onto snow covered and/or frozen roadways will likely create icy surfaces. Please use caution if you will be traveling this weekend, and stay tuned to forecast updates.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Anchorage; Matanuska Valley; Western Kenai Peninsula

cap:parameter.value: PERIODS OF RAIN AND FREEZING RAIN THIS WEEKEND

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued December 19 at 8:53PM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
ESFMTR
AN ACTIVE STORM TRACK ACROSS NORTHERN CALIFORNIA WILL BRING MODERATE RAINFALL AND AN INCREASED POTENTIAL FOR RAPID RIVER RISES ON NORTH BAY CREEKS AND STREAMS
* WHATThe storm door is wide open with a very active storm track forecast to impact Northern California. Wet and unsettled weather will bring periods of light to moderate rainfall to the region with the biggest impact expected over the North Bay. The first couple of storms that are forecast to move across the North Bay Saturday and again on Sunday, will likely prime the soils resulting in quicker and more noteworthy rises of area streams and creeks by the time the third storm moves in. This third storm that is expected to impact the North Bay on Monday and Tuesday is gearing up to be the strongest and wettest of the series. The higher elevations of the North Bay will likely see around 2.0 to 4.0 inches of precipitation while North Bay valleys see around 1.30 to 3.0 inches.
Main stem rivers are forecast to remain below flood stage; however, the exceedance probabilities (of rising above flood stage) across the North Bay show a high potential for exceeding flood thresholds early next week. The Russian River at Guerneville - GUEC1 has a 39% of exceeding the Action/Monitor stage and a 34% of exceeding the Minor Flood stage . SHEC1- Napa near Saint Helena has a 43% of exceeding the Action/Monitor stage and a 20% of exceeding the Minor Flood stage. APCC1- Napa near Napa has a 30% of exceeding the Action/Monitor stage and a 11% of exceeding the Minor Flood stage . A few other rivers to keep an eye on that show higher probability of reaching Action/Monitor or Minor flood stage according to the latest CNRFC forecast are CTIC1 - Laguna De Santa Rosa at Stony Pt Rd near Cotati has a 80-95% probability of reaching Action/Monitor Stage and a 40-70% probability of reaching Minor flood stage as early as Saturday with chances increasing as the weekend progresses. MWEC1 - Mark West Creek at Mirabel Heights now has a 91% probability of reaching Action/Monitor Stage and a 52% probability of reaching Minor flood stage on Tuesday. GEYC1 - Russian River at Geyserville has a 52% probability of reaching Action/Monitor Stage and a 41% probability of reaching Minor flood stage on Tuesday.
* WHERESonoma and Napa Counties. Latest model guidance suggests the North Bay will receive the greatest accumulation of precipitation with the heaviest rainfall expected over the North Bay coastal range and mountains.
* WHENSaturday through Wednesday. Light to Moderate rainfall expected over the North Bay Saturday through Tuesday. The heaviest rainfall accumulation is expected Monday into Tuesday.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...In addition to the moderate rainfall and localized ponding of water in low-lying or poorly drained areas, such as freeway offramps. Locally strong and gusty winds may result in downed trees, and potential power outages.
Confidence is high that we will receive rainfall from this system however, confidence is moderate with respect to the exact location and timing of the most intense rainfall. Details regarding this storm will likely change as the system nears. Therefore, stay tuned to the latest forecast for the most up to date weather information.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Marin Coastal Range; Sonoma Coastal Range; North Bay Interior Mountains; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; North Bay Interior Valleys

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued December 19 at 9:44AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
AQAPSR
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued a PM-2.5 High Pollution Advisory for the Phoenix Metro Area through Friday.
This means that ongoing stagnant weather conditions combined with existing airborne fine particulate levels may result in local fine particulate concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates.
Fine particulate matter - also known as PM-2.5 - is an air contaminant that can aggravate heart and lung disease conditions, especially in older adults, children, and those with asthma. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.
Consolidate your travel, reduce or eliminate fireplace use, refrain from outdoor burning, and avoid using gas-powered lawn equipment.
For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/phoenix or call 602-771-2300.

entry.summary:
AQAPSR
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued a PM-2.5 High Pollution Advisory for the Phoenix Metro Area through Friday.
This means that ongoing stagnant weather conditions combined with existing airborne fine particulate levels may result in local fine particulate concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates.
Fine particulate matter - also known as PM-2.5 - is an air contaminant that can aggravate heart and lung disease conditions, especially in older adults, children, and those with asthma. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.
Consolidate your travel, reduce or eliminate fireplace use, refrain from outdoor burning, and avoid using gas-powered lawn equipment.
For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/phoenix or call 602-771-2300.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Maricopa, AZ

cap:parameter.value: PM-2.5 HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR MARICOPA COUNTY INCLUDING THE PHOENIX METRO THROUGH FRIDAY

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued December 19 at 6:20AM PST until December 20 at 3:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast, Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.
* WHEN...Through Friday afternoon. .
* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Del Norte; Northern Humboldt Coast; Southwestern Humboldt; Mendocino Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH FRIDAY AFTERNOON
